issues.title: RFC 6991 import: inet versus yang prefix
issues.author: bclaise
issues.body:
| Prefix | Yang Module            | Reference    |
| ------ | ---------------------- | ------------ |
| isisnt | ietf-l3-isis-topology  | RFCXXX       |
| yang   | ietf-yang-types        | {{!RFC6991}} |

In most YANG modules, the prefix for RFC6991 import is "inet".
Ex: see https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc9398#name-tree-diagrams section 1.3

comments.author: bclaise
comments.body:
After doing a few grep into https://github.com/YangModels/yang/tree/main/standard/ietf/RFC, I stand corrected.
yang is for ietf-yang-types
inet is for ietf-inet-types

issues.title: ietf-topology information model?
issues.author: bclaise
issues.body:
"The topology information of a domain can be structured according to ietf-topology information model"

Do we mean:
The topology information of a domain can be structured according to ietf-network-topology YANG (RFC 8345)

comments.author: bclaise
comments.body: Hi Oscar, my point is that RFC 8345 is data model and not an information model. See https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc3444

issues.title: ISIS Links / neighbors
issues.author: OlgaHuawei
issues.body:
I shared my comments with Pablo at the last meeting about the ISIS Links:
- ISIS Topology Diagram does not have augmentation for links, although the YANG module later does show it
- why do we have neighbors in node if we have links?
- metric1 and metric2 is already in the link in RFC8346, why do we have metric added as a property of the tp?

comments.author: ppavon
comments.body:
Hi!

Agree in removing neighbors: redundant with the existence of links (i.e. adjacencies)

As for the metrics:
- Suggest to keep the ISIS weight there in ISIS YANG. The metric1 and metric2 may be used by other protocols for any reason (e.g an estiation of the latency, not related to ISIS operation)

issues.title: IS-IS Topology Tree Diagram
issues.author: OlgaHuawei

issues.title: isis-status
issues.author: OlgaHuawei
issues.body:
Node has attributes split into isis-timer-attributes and isis-status, where isis-status has some rw attributes. Why do we have status for something that has write access?
TP has isis-termination-point-attributes
Link has isis-termination-point-attributes

Is there a good reason to have  level in isis-status for node and that it is not in isis-status in tp?
My suggestion is to just have isis-node-attributes, this simplifies and can be done as a recommendation for the basic extensions.

comments.author: ppavon
comments.body:
As for the level attribute, I would suggest (following a conversation with
Olga the last day):
- Having a level attribute at node level, that is mandatory.
- Optionally, when the node has Level1-2, each TP may have a level
attribute. This is to cover the (relatively frequent) situations when a
Level-1-2 node, has some interfaces restricted to be just of one level.

Pablo


El mar, 27 jun 2023 a las 18:17, OlgaHuawei ***@***.***>)
escribió:

> Node has attributes split into isis-timer-attributes and isis-status,
> where isis-status has some rw attributes. Why do we have status for
> something that has write access?
> TP has isis-termination-point-attributes
> Link has isis-termination-point-attributes
>
> Is there a good reason to have level in isis-status for node and that it
> is not in isis-status in tp?
> My suggestion is to just have isis-node-attributes, this simplifies and
> can be done as a recommendation for the basic extensions.

issues.title: OSPF Area and RFC8345 Issue
issues.author: OlgaHuawei
issues.body:
IS-IS model can be changed to have OSPF areas as networks when RFC8345 is improved.

The draft draft-havel-opsawg-digital-map-00 talks about the Digital Map modelling experience and what we believe is missing in the basic RFC8345 model. One of the things identified as missing is links between networks, as links can belong to 1 network only. We modelled IS-IS areas as networks in our PoC and there was an issue how to model the links between different OSPF areas. We added network-id as ref as well for the destination . IS-IS model can be changed to have OSPF areas as networks when RFC8345 is improved, the effort has started to come up with drafts to propose backward compatible solutions for all of the things identified as missing from RFC8345. The links between the networks will be one of the proposals.

The following is the text from the draft-havel-opsawg-digital-map-00 draft:
[6.1.3. ][Links Between Networks]
The RFC8345 defines all links as belonging to one network instance and having the source and destination as node and termination point only, not allowing to link to termination point of another network. This does not allow for links between networks in the case of multi-domains or partitioning. The only way would be to model each domain as node and have links between them.

We modelled OSPF and IS-IS Areas as networks during the PoC and we needed to extend the capability to have links between different areas. We added network reference as well to the source / destination of the link. The RFC8795 also augments links with external-domain info for the case of links that connect different domains.

issues.title: Paragraph on simulation and on use cases
issues.author: ppavon
issues.body:
As requested by Oscar, I include below some paragraphs related to the simulation / capacity planning and other use cases, potentially to include in a use cases section. Please see below some suggested writing:

The standardization of the NBI of SDN controllers for IP networks, permits the connection of third party tools covering specialized cases. Among them, the tools for network performance optimization, and network dimensioning and planning would benefit from retrieving from the NBI an abstracted view of the IP network topology and IGP configurations. 

As for IS-IS, the NBI should export enough information to permit these tools simulating the IP routing at a macroscopic flow level. That is, simulating how IP-level traffic demands would be forwarded, after ISIS convergence is reached, and from there estimating, using appropriate mathematical models, related KPIs like the occupation in the links or end-to-end latencies. 

Being able to simulate the IP demands routing, enables multiple use cases like:

* What-if analysis. Estimation of the network KPIs in modified network situations. For instance, failure situations, traffic anomaly situations, addition or deletion of new adjacencies, IGP weight reconfigurations.
* Failure analysis. Systematic and massive test of the network under multiple simulated failure situations, evaluating the network fault tolerance properties, and using mathematical models to derive statistical network availability metrics.
* Network design & capacity planning. Dimensioning or redesign of the IP infrastructure to satisfy target KPI metrics under existing or forecasted traffic demands.

comments.author: bclaise
comments.body: In order to speed up the process, I took the freedom to take your proposal into account, modify it, add some other sections in  https://github.com/oscargdd/draft-ogondio-opsawg-isis-topology/pull/12

issues.title: Implementation Status
issues.author: bclaise
issues.body:
I updated (in my temp version) the Implementation Status section with 

# Implementation Status

   Note to the RFC-Editor: Please remove this section before publishing.

# Huawei Digital Map PoC Status

   As mentioned in {{?draft-havel-opsawg-digital-map}},  a Digital Map PoC with a real lab has been built, based on multi-
   vendor devices, with {{!RFC8345}} as the base YANG module for the topology building blocks. This PoC successfully modelled
   IS-IS routing (among other technologies and layers), but it needs to be further aligned with this latest developments in this draft.


Pablo, did I hear correctly about a second implementation?

comments.author: ppavon
comments.body:
Hi!

E-lighthouse Network Solutions (https://e-lighthouse.com/, start-up I where I am co-founder) has an implementation in an ongoing POC in 2023, collaborating with Telefonica. The POC is targeted for a lab network (ongoing) and to a pilot of a segment of Telefonica group production network by the end of 2023. We read from the NBI of an IP SDN controller, collecting IP info in a multivendor deployment. The NBI follows an ietf-network based model. This POC has already successfully retrieved ISIS and IP topology info, and then is able to simulate the network behavior under different (simulated) changes, and cover the what-if, failure analysis, dimensioning and other use cases mentioned in the use cases paragraphs I suggested

comments.author: bclaise
comments.body:
Hi, 

Great. Please write a new sub section.

This is what I added. https://github.com/oscargdd/draft-ogondio-opsawg-isis-topology/pull/12/files
 => Implementation Status

First, Oscar needs to accept this OR

comments.author: oscargdd
comments.body:
PR accepted and fixed the whitespaces. 

@ppavon can you add the paragraph now?

issues.title: Write YANG objects
issues.author: bclaise
issues.body:
First, I updated the security considerations section with the right references from https://wiki.ietf.org/group/ops/yang-security-guidelines

"There are a number of data nodes defined in this YANG module that are writable/creatable/deletable (i.e., config true, which is the default). These data nodes may be considered sensitive or vulnerable in some network environments. Write operations (e.g., edit-config) to these data nodes without proper protection can have a negative effect on network operations."

If we agree that WRITE is for simulation, then we have no "negative effect on network operations".

Also, we want to add some information about the readable data (see the template)
